title: 110_hr3148
content: The "Child Pornography Elimination Act of 2007" mandates a minimum sentence of 2 to 15 years for possession of child pornography. Section 13032 of Title 42, United States Code, is strengthened to ensure effective reporting of child pornography. Section 227(b)(2) of the Victims of Child Abuse Act of 1990 is amended to impose fines for providers of electronic communication services or remote computing services who knowingly or negligently fail to report child abuse. Fines range from $50,000 to $300,000 depending on the severity and repetition of the offense. The Federal Communications Commission can impose civil penalties of up to $50,000 for an initial failure to report child abuse and up to $100,000 for any subsequent failures. The FCC has the authority to enforce these penalties and will establish regulations for administrative review in consultation with the Attorney General. SEC. 4 amends Section 2252(a) of title 18, United States Code to include knowingly accessing child pornography with intent to view. SEC. 5 adds a conspiracy provision for Chapter 77 offenses. SEC. 6 mandates restitution for certain child sex offenses. Chapter 117 of title 18, United States Code is amended to include mandatory restitution for offenses under this chapter. The court shall order the defendant to pay the victim the full amount of their losses, including medical expenses, in addition to any other penalties authorized by law. Restitution orders will be enforced in the same manner as other orders under section 3663A. The term 'full amount of the victim's losses' includes costs for medical services, therapy, transportation, lost income, attorney's fees, and other losses as a result of the offense. A restitution order under this section is mandatory and cannot be declined by the court. The issuance of a restitution order under this section is mandatory and cannot be declined by the court, regardless of the defendant's economic circumstances or the victim's compensation from insurance. The term 'victim' is defined as the individual harmed by a crime, including minors, incapacitated individuals, or deceased victims. SEC. 7 amends the definition of illicit sexual conduct to include the production of child pornography. SEC. 8 expands the use of the sex trafficking statute. SEC. 8 expands the use of the sex trafficking statute by amending various sections of title 18, United States Code to include references to section 1591.
